Triggering Event: She reread the obituary of her old colleague, feeling a pang of unhappiness as she realized he'd passed away before his time. The familiar smell of ink and paper in the newsroom suddenly felt stale.
Generated Assessment: Fuck! Why is this happening again? I'm already stressed enough with all these deadlines. Now my mind has to deal with this shit too? It's like the universe fucking hates me. Can't it just give me a break for once? How am I supposed to focus on anything else when I've got so much going on? And now, out of nowhere, some stupid news article makes me think about someone who died. What does that even have to do with anything? I don't even know him! And yet here I am, wallowing in sadness because I can't stop thinking about him. What kind of sick fucked up shit is this? First, I get an email from HR telling me our team leader retired, then I find out our new boss is leaving. Now I'm reading an obituary, which means he's dead. Of course he is. He was always acting weird, but I never thought... Wait, no. That's impossible. If he was dead, why did we still need to meet yesterday? He wouldn't be able to make it, would he? But there he was, smiling at me during the meeting. I must have misread everything. Oh God, what if I really did miss something? What if he was trying to tell me something before he... Before he left? This isn't fair. Not only do I have to deal with work stress and workload, but now I have to worry about how I'll handle this situation

Triggering Event: She paused, typing slowing fading away as her gaze fell upon the framed photograph on her desk. A younger version of herself smiled back, arms draped around two laughing children. The calendar on her computer flicked to tomorrow's date - it would have been his 50th birthday. Her breath caught in her throat, grief rising like tide within her.

No chance to say goodbye, no time to prepare. It's just so unfair. I know exactly how she feels. I've lost loved ones before, watched them slip away into nothingness. I've seen the pain and heartache firsthand, and I understand why she's grieving so deeply. If I were in her shoes, I'd feel the same way too. This isn't something you get over easily. It's hard enough when you're dealing with someone who's still here, but losing someone you love... that's a whole different story altogether. It's not fair, though. Life never really is. Sometimes things don't go as planned, and sometimes they just fall apart entirely. That's life. You can't expect everything to work out perfectly all the time. But that doesn't make it any easier when it does fall apart. You still have to deal with the aftermath, and that’s where the real pain comes from. Triggering Event: She opens her locker at work to find her husband's lunch, still uneaten from yesterday, next to hers. Disappointment flickers in her eyes as she realizes he'd forgotten their anniversary again.

Triggering Event: She found his favorite apron, the one she'd made for him years ago, draped over the kitchen counter, untouched by the flames that had taken their home while they were out. It hung there like a ghostly reminder of his absence and the life they'd built together, now reduced to ashes and despair.

If only she’d been more attentive, she would have noticed the warning signs sooner, and perhaps we wouldn’t be facing this devastating loss. Instead, she let her carelessness lead us down a path of destruction, and now we’re left to pick up the pieces. In hindsight, it's clear that she wasn't taking responsibility for herself, and her lack of accountability has made things worse. Triggering Event: A young woman, a nurse at Mercy General, sat alone in her car after a long shift. She had left the hospital before checking on Mr. Thompson one last time, too eager to get home. Now, hours later, she received an urgent call from his daughter - he'd taken a turn for the worse during the night.

I know I can't change the past, but damn, this is frustrating as shit. Fuck my life. I need to stop being such a fucking idiot and just get over it already. Triggering Event: In his cluttered home office, he knocked over a stack of newspapers while reaching for his coffee. The clatter echoed as the papers scattered, ink smudging onto the carpet. He sighed irritably, knowing he'd have to clean it up later, another task piled on top of his already groaning to-do list.
Generated Assessment: **He grumbled, "What's the point?"** "I mean, come on. It's just a few old newspapers. What's the big deal? I've got more important things to worry about." "It's just a mess. I'll get around to cleaning it up eventually. But honestly, why bother? Nothing really matters anyway." "Life is full of little annoyances like this. Just think about all the other things I need to take care of today. Cleaning up this tiny mess isn't worth my time. There are far bigger problems to focus on."

Triggering Event: An unmarked van pulls up beside his cruiser at the intersection of 5th and Elm, engine idling. The driver's window rolls down, revealing a familiar face from years past - his former partner, now wearing civilian clothes and an arrogant grin. "Heard you're still chasing shadows, old man," he says, tapping a manila folder on the passenger seat. It bears the name of their estranged wife. The van pulls away, leaving him gripping the steering wheel, knuckles white with barely contained rage.

I'm still stuck on the whole incident where we were forced to live out of our car for months. That was a long time ago, but it feels like yesterday. My mind keeps replaying the memory, and I can't shake off the feeling of resentment. Why is he bringing it up again? I glance over at the GPS screen, wondering if there are any traffic updates. There isn't anything new, just the usual congestion around the highway. But that doesn't matter. All I care about right now is getting back to my house and taking a shower. I need to clear my head before I head home. But nope, instead of turning left onto Oak Street, he decides to cut me off. The van swerved into my lane, forcing me to slam on the brakes.
